channel.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
channel.description:
This is the first actual program I've written in a while. Although I don't really play Runescape, I thought it would be useful to some other people. The download includes the executable and visual studio solution.
Here's the paste bin source if you don't feel like downloading, but want to take a look:
http://paste2.org/p/65569
Update: It now shows an image of the item, and the 7 Day and 30 Day graph.

item.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Moparisthebest:

…making it useless for most people…

you have a poor grasp on reality

Read full topic

item.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
item.dc:creator: @Weebs Weebs
item.description:
@Weebs wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:227542”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=299002.msg2407689#msg2407689 date=1219783857]

java isn’t a library, it’s a language

and a library?
[/quote]

Which also happens to have a runtime that runs on more Operating systems than only one. C# is a non-machine code (it uses bytecode, like Java) language that only runs on one operating system, making it useless for most people. That is why I prefer Java over C#, others may have other reasons.

Ontopic:
Good idea, thanks for sharing. :)[/quote]

The mono library works pretty well with .NET on Linux/OS X. The only thing I have to complain about it is that if you’re using System.Windows.Forms (Like my program) it ends up looking like shit on other OS’s besides Windows. Although you are able to use the GTK+ library which looks great on Windows and *nix.

Also, I’ve added graphs and an image of the item to the program. Figured some people would like that.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:227542”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=299002.msg2407689#msg2407689 date=1219783857]

java isn’t a library, it’s a language

and a library?
[/quote]

Which also happens to have a runtime that runs on more Operating systems than only one. C# is a non-machine code (it uses bytecode, like Java) language that only runs on one operating system, making it useless for most people. That is why I prefer Java over C#, others may have other reasons.

Ontopic:
Good idea, thanks for sharing. :)[/quote]I was under the impression that C# has the ability to JIT. Just In Time compile.

So, unlike Java which is always “talking” to the JVM, C# only has to “talk” to the .NET runtime once, before it is compiled natively.

EDIT:

More info :

JIT is the process of compiling MSIL code units just when needed at runtime. The JIT compiler in the Common Language Runtime (CLR) compiles MSIL instructions to native machine code as a .NET application is being executed. Compilation occurs when a method is called and is not compiled more than once during program execution; because, JIT-compiled code is cached in memory.

All libraries mentioned are built into C#. It only needs to compile itself once, before it is compiled natively.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:227542”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=299002.msg2407689#msg2407689 date=1219783857]

java isn’t a library, it’s a language

and a library?
[/quote]

Which also happens to have a runtime that runs on more Operating systems than only one. C# is a non-machine code (it uses bytecode, like Java) language that only runs on one operating system, making it useless for most people. That is why I prefer Java over C#, others may have other reasons.

Ontopic:
Good idea, thanks for sharing. :)[/quote]

.NET gets compiled through JIT. You can also explicitly compile to a Windows binary, that will probably be able to run in wine if you would like. However, Mono is still a good solution.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
item.dc:creator: @i_pk_pjers_i i_pk_pjers_i
item.description:
@i_pk_pjers_i wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:227542”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=299002.msg2407689#msg2407689 date=1219783857]

java isn’t a library, it’s a language

and a library?
[/quote]

Which also happens to have a runtime that runs on more Operating systems than only one. C# is a non-machine code (it uses bytecode, like Java) language that only runs on one operating system, making it useless for most people. That is why I prefer Java over C#, others may have other reasons.

Ontopic:
Good idea, thanks for sharing. :)[/quote]Not necessarily true, linux can emulate it in wine and there is some programs for linux that use .net, but java is easier to use on multiple playforms because you don’t have to change any code.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:227542”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=299002.msg2407689#msg2407689 date=1219783857]

java isn’t a library, it’s a language

and a library?
[/quote]

Which also happens to have a runtime that runs on more Operating systems than only one. C# is a non-machine code (it uses bytecode, like Java) language that only runs on one operating system, making it useless for most people. That is why I prefer Java over C#, others may have other reasons.

Ontopic:
Good idea, thanks for sharing. :)[/quote]
That’s why you prefer the Java library over the .NET library. C# has nothing to do with the OS, but of course you know this
Mono is, as far as I’ve seen, a very viable solution for running .net 2.0 code on Linux.
The only thing C# itself does that is somewhat less platform portable is make it easy to call unmanaged platform specific library functions (the ‘extern’ keyword). In Java you have to go through all the JNI crap.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
item.dc:creator: @Weebs Weebs
item.description:
@Weebs wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:5, topic:227542”][quote author=Weebs link=topic=299002.msg2402672#msg2402672 date=1219527730]

One suggestion,
You should parse the page using the XmlDocument class in the System.Xml namespace, rather than splitting strings.

I’m somewhat familiar with XML, but not totally. How would I go about parsing an HTML page into an XML file?
[/quote]
Well, come to think of it, you wouldn’t want to use XmlDocument, but rather an XmlTextReader. You would just be able to loop through every element in the HTML document, and pick out the ones you need, then extract their value with the InnerText property of XmlNode.[/quote]

Thanks, I’ll check this out.

xEnt:

i use C#, what’s up with most ppl on mitb hatin on it. It’s good to balance between java/c# as it’s not hard to do.

A lot of people are elitist ass holes. They refuse to accept that there’s good libraries out that besides Java.

item.title: [C#]Grand Exchange Price Grabber
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Weebs, post:3, topic:227542”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=299002.msg2402047#msg2402047 date=1219504817]
One suggestion,
You should parse the page using the XmlDocument class in the System.Xml namespace, rather than splitting strings.
[/quote]

I’m somewhat familiar with XML, but not totally. How would I go about parsing an HTML page into an XML file?[/quote]
Well, come to think of it, you wouldn’t want to use XmlDocument, but rather an XmlTextReader. You would just be able to loop through every element in the HTML document, and pick out the ones you need, then extract their value with the InnerText property of XmlNode.

Read full topic
